title: The Formation of the First Parties

content.text: In mid-1990, the first non-communist political party was organized: the Croatian Social Liberal Union. This was soon followed by the formation of numerous political parties, among which the Croatian Democratic Union, led by political dissident Dr. Franjo Tuđman, played a prominent role.

The Croatian Democratic Alliance (HDS) of Dr. Marko Veselica became the first political party in Croatia to establish a local branch in the Municipality of Sinj after the introduction of the multi-party system. The meeting was held on January 21, 1990, on the playground of the elementary school in Hrvace, where the party held a second gathering on April 8, 1990. A major pre-election rally of the Coalition of the People's Accord (of which the HDS was a member) was held on April 17, 1990, at the same location.
The HDS was also the first political party to hold a meeting in the village of Otok, on February 11, 1990.

The Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) was founded in Vrlika on February 22, 1990. At that time, several parties were established (SK-SDP, HDS, HDZ, HNS, SHS, and HSLS), each aiming to win the elections or at least participate in the government. The Croatian Party of Rights was later established, but it was not officially registered.

On March 23, 1990, Dr. Franjo Tuđman arrived in the village of Brnaze. The following day, the largest pre-election rally (about 30,000 people) in the Municipality of Sinj was held, where Dr. Tuđman gave a speech. He presented a clear vision of a sovereign Croatian state, which created great enthusiasm among the many members and supporters of the HDZ.
